Overfelt, Yerba Buena, and James Lick.  The Santa Clara County has certified that each of the four schools have met the “Sufficiency of Textbooks” requirement.  The certification for the schools that are not visited is done by the principal.  Each principal, from the non-visited schools submit a signed “Certification of Textbook Sufficiency”.

SUBJECT:
Hold Public Hearing at Approximately 6:10 p.m. regarding Proposed Adoption of Resolution #2012/2013-03 and to Establish Criteria for Determining Whether School Construction Projects are Substantially Complex and Subject to More than Five Percent Retention and to Delegate Authority to Designate Substantially Complex Projects
	 
Effective January 1, 2012, Public Contract Code section 7201 was amended to place a 5% cap on retentions held by school districts in connection with public works projects.  Section 7201(b)(4) provides an exception to the 5% cap rule “on specific projects where the governing body of the public entity or designee, including, but not limited to, a general manager or other director of an appropriate department, has approved a finding during a properly noticed and normally scheduled public hearing and prior to bid that the project is substantially complex and therefore requires a higher retention amount than 5% and the awarding entity includes both this finding and the actual retention amount in the bid documents.”  Section 7201 does not define “substantially complex.”
	 
The District’s general practice in connection with Measure G and Measure E has been to implement a 10% retention due to the overall complexity of the District’s projects and the Measure G and Measure E bond programs.  To ensure compliance with Section 7201 as amended, Administration requests that the Board hold a public hearing on this item and the proposed Resolution 2012/2013-03 to obtain community and stakeholder input on the criteria proposed for determining whether projects are complex thereby justifying a higher retention and delegating the authority to make such findings to the Superintendent, the Associate Superintendent of Business Services and the Superintendent’s designee.

SUBJECT:
Adopt Resolution #2012/2013-03 Establishing Criteria for Determining Whether School Construction Projects are Substantially Complex and Subject to More Than Five Percent Retention and to Delegate Authority to Designate Substantially Complex Projects
	 
Effective January 1, 2012, Public Contract Code section 7201 was amended to place a 5% cap on retentions held by school districts in connection with public works projects.  Section 7201(b)(4) provides an exception to the 5% cap rule “on specific projects where the governing body of the public entity or designee, including, but not limited to, a general manager or other director of an appropriate department, has approved a finding during a properly noticed and normally scheduled public hearing and prior to bid that the project is substantially complex and therefore requires a higher retention amount than 5% and the awarding entity includes both this finding and the actual retention amount in the bid documents.”  Section 7201 does not define “substantially complex.”
	 
Pursuant to the proposed resolution, the criteria to be used in making that determination would be as follows:
	 
(1)    Whether the Project is subject to higher safety standards than other public works projects;
(2)    Whether the Project is subject to additional levels of inspection beyond those normally required for other public works project;
(3)    Whether the Project is subject to design approval by the State of California Division of the State Architect;
(4)    Whether the Project is multi-phased or involves unique scheduling or sequencing or other critical path methods or other issues;
(5)    Whether it is a Project in which alternative delivery methods including but not limited to lease-leaseback or design-build are utilized; and/or
(6)    Whether the Project will have specialized systems and/or safety measures included in its design to protect District students, teachers, staff and/or visitors.
	 
The District’s general practice in connection with Measure G and Measure E has been to implement a 10% retention due to the overall complexity of the District’s projects and the Measure G and Measure E bond programs.  To ensure compliance with Section 7201 as amended, Administration requests that the Board adopt the proposed resolution establishing the criteria to be used in determining whether a project is substantially complex and thereby justifying a retention higher than 5%, and delegating the authority to make such findings to the Superintendent, the Associate Superintendent of Business Services and the Superintendent’s designee as appropriate but subject to ratification by the Board.
	 
	 
	 
Funding Source:
Measure G, Measure E, and Capitol Facilities, as applicable
	 
Fiscal Impact:
To be determined
	 
Recommendation:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees adopt Resolution #2012/2012-03 as proposed.

Resolution to Stop the Special Exemptions Act
(Proposition 32)
	 
Resolution No: 2012/2013-06
	 
	 
WHEREAS, the real agenda behind Proposition 32, the Special Exemptions Act, is to silence the voice of teachers, nurses, firefighters, and other middle-class workers in speaking up for students and everyday Californians; and   
	 
WHEREAS, the Special Exemptions Act  purports to be about stopping special interest money in politics, when in reality, it will not curb billionaire businessmen and Super PACs from continuing to infuse massive amounts of money into swaying the electorate; and 
	 
WHEREAS, corporations already outspend unions by more than 15 to 1 in politics; and 
	 
WHEREAS, this measure allows corporations to continue to make political contributions without restrictions; and 
	 
WHEREAS, this initiative will virtually prevent teachers from being able to advocate for such issues as state funding initiatives; Class Size Reduction; school art, music, and sports programs; and school health and safety improvements; and  
	 
WHEREAS, this initiative will also have major implications for teachers in being able to advocate locally for parcel taxes, school bonds, and community improvement ballot measures; and  
	 
WHEREAS, if the voices of teachers and the middle class are restricted from speaking on important local, state and national issues, it will have serious consequences for the future of public education, our communities, and our state; now, therefore,
	 
BE IT RESOLVED that the East Side Union High School District Board of Trustees supports the right of teachers, school and public employees, and labor unions to make their voices heard politically; and 
	 
BE IT FURTHER RESOLVED that the East Side Union High School District Board of Trustees does not support the Special Exemptions Act and urges voters to vote no on Proposition 32 in the November 2012 election.

SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action regarding Balanced-Budget Blueprint
	 
	 
A Balanced-Budget Blueprint for Action
		 
The Need for Change
The long-term future financial viability of the East Side Union High School District has reached a sense of urgency.  Based on current budget assumptions, it is estimated that beginning in FY 2015-16, the District’s reserves will be mostly depleted and the District will be facing a funding cliff.  This situation is primarily a result of millions in lost revenues from the State and a continuing decline in district enrollment.  Although, the District has taken decisive actions over the past 4 years to address the budget shortfall and has reduced expenditures by over $51 million, it has not been enough.  
	 
The School District is now facing what perhaps may be its biggest challenge and that is “time”.  The District does have a window of opportunity from which to make thoughtful and deliberate decisions, however, that window is narrowing.  The District simply can’t afford to continue operating with a mantra of business as usual because it would require more money than we have, and our current operating structure has already been reduced to alarming levels.  The District needs and requires more options in order to ensure long-term fiscal stability. Through the District’s proposed strategic blueprint, we hope to achieve two simple goals: A continuation of high quality district programs and services for staff and students, and a balanced budget by FY 2015-16. 
	 
Why This Time Is So Vital
Even after making drastic budget cuts over the past 4 years totaling $51 million, the School District still faces a financial shortfall estimated at $23 million over the next three years. The sheer size of this deficit demands dramatic rethinking and a plan of action to ensure the long-term viability of the District.
	 
Rising operational costs, on-going State funding cuts, and the end of Federal stimulus dollars have highlighted deep structural budget issues that must be addressed urgently and strategically.
	 
Recently, the District received a letter from the County in acceptance of the District’s 2012-13 budget, however, the County noted in their letter that they were concerned about the District’s on-going fiscal imbalance and they recommended that the District develop an action plan which would bring the District’s budget into balance by FY 2015-16. 
	 
What Does This Mean for Parents, Students, and Staff?
The District wants to ensure that there is a process for engaging our stakeholders in the discussion to ensure that each group’s needs and priorities are clearly understood with regard to budgetary realignment.  The scale and pace of any change can sometimes be overwhelming, but the ultimate goal is to ensure the preservation of high quality district programs and services for all East Side students and staff. In addition, the District would like to ensure that there is minimal impact on all groups and that any actions are made in an equitable, fair, streamlined and open process.  
	 
Our Strategy for Transformation
Our long-term strategy for transformation must begin soon.  The time for change is now. Faced with a continuing financial crisis and no apparent relief in the foreseeable future, the East Side Union High School District must begin the painstaking process of structural budget transformation. The goal is to ensure that the District remains fiscally solvent and is able to develop a soft landing approach with regard to budgetary actions and/or recommendations to bring the budget back into balance by FY 2015-16.  This budgetary transformation is about the long-term preservation of programs and services which impact the students, staff, and the community of East Side Union High School District.  All are vital parts of the public education system in East Side.  Only by addressing the current challenges and opportunities of our current budget situation in a focused and systematic approach will we be able to ensure long-term fiscal stability.  
	 
RECOMMENDED ESUHSD BUDGET 
BLUEPRINT FOR ACTION
Communicate Strategic Road Map to the Board for proposed Blueprint for addressing the District’s long-term Budget Imbalance;  (September 2012) 
Hire a Consultant with the following objectives; (September  2012)
To review the budget assumptions and analyze each major revenue and expenditure category for the General Fund and ancillary funds to assess for reasonableness; 
To provide a comparative analysis of revenues, expenses, fund balance reserves, and staffing as compared to similar size and type school districts; 
To interview and engage key internal staff and bargaining union members in the process for input in developing a framework for multi-year strategies;  
To determine and/or confirm the extent of the structural deficit; 1) Identify the size and scope of the problem; 2) Make revenue and expenditure recommendations for reducing and/or eliminating the structural deficit, and 3) Develop a timeline for actions to occur in order for the District to eliminate the structural deficit and align the budget by fiscal year 2015-16. 
Consultant presents the recommendations to the Board for review; (December 2012) 
District will solicit input on the plan from all internal and external stakeholders including parents, students, community partners, district staff, and other stakeholders to help inform about the plan recommendations; (January – February 2013) 
Review stakeholder feedback and recommend actions for the Boards consideration: (February  –  May 2013)
